csv utilities¶

simple csv - set of simple utilities for handling csv

For all functions:¶

some common keywords are listed for convenience. Only non-None keywords are passed.

Convert to csv:¶

in general, can just use default settings, which are of form convert_ABC_to_csv(lstofABC[,path) where ‘ABC’ is list or dict and ‘lstofABC’ is a list of lists or dicts. ‘path’ is optional.

if no path given, defaults to inserting the time into the filename

read from csv:¶

general format: read_csv_to_ABC(path) -> ABC where path is a path to a csv file and ABC is ‘list’ or ‘dict’. All keywords for python csv module are accepted, also possible to specify a header row to get titles/keys, etc

All functions work with lists, dicts, or any object that works similarly

simpleutils.simplecsv.convert_dict_to_csv(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Deprecated, wrapper for simplecsv.write_dict

simpleutils.simplecsv.convert_list_to_csv(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

deprecated, wrapper for write_list

simpleutils.simplecsv.read_csv_to_dict(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

deprecated, wrapper for read_to_dict

simpleutils.simplecsv.read_csv_to_list(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

deprecated, wrapper for read_to_list

simpleutils.simplecsv.read_to_dict(path, dialect='excel', delimiter=None, quotechar=None, encoding=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

reads the csv at ‘path’ and outputs a dict with keywords from the firstline (so, the column titles) any keywords for csvreader can be passed through if desired). path can be fileobject or system path Keywords are listed for convenience, only non-None are kept

simpleutils.simplecsv.read_to_list(path, dialect='excel', delimiter=None, quotechar=None, encoding=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

reads the csv at ‘path’ and outputs a list with all lines maintained (so, the column titles) any keywords for csvreader can be passed through if desired)

simpleutils.simplecsv.write_dict(lstofdicts, filename=None, header_row=None, fieldnames=None, dialect='excel', **kwargs)[source]¶

Takes dict and converts to csv, see csv.DictWriter for more, **kwargs are passed on, default filename is DictReader(csvfile[, fieldnames=None[, restkey=None[, restval=None[, dialect='excel'[, *args, **kwds]]]]])`() Use keyword arguments so you don’t have to worry about position.

Parameters:
  • lstofdicts – list of dicts to be converted to csv
  • filename – path/fileobject/None for storing csv. See simplefile.get_fileobject() for more.
  • header_row (integer) – if given, pops that item in the list of of lstofdicts and uses it as headers (assumes it has a keys() method.
simpleutils.simplecsv.write_list(lst, filename=None, header_row=0, num_columns=None, delimiter=None, quotechar=None, quoting=None, dialect='excel', **kwargs)[source]¶

Takes a list of data (generally list of list) and writes it to a file as a csv.

Parameters:
  • header_row – specifies index where titles are located (becomes first row of csv)
  • filename – default is pretty_time, filename can also be a fileobject (passed through get_fileobject())

All other args passed to writer, args with None are written for convenience reminder. Default filename is pretty_time(), filename can also be a fileobject
